Posts.Content:
To answer your question about
 the wound seeping fluid: this may be a sign of infection. As long as there is infection present the wound will not close. Has the doctor taken a culture of the fluid? That would tell him if it is infected and what bacteria is causing the infection. That determines what antibiotic to use. FK
Posts.Title: Abdominal wound issues after Tram Flap Reconstruction

Posts.Content:
My father had a similar situation following 
open heart surgery. It took a total of four surgeries to get the hole to close after two years. The doctors in Florida had also given up, but my brother then brought him to Utah (where he lives) and found a new team of doctors who first retreated the mrsa with different antibiotics and got the wound to stop "weeping" and then did another big surgery to get the hole to close. That was a year and a half ago and it has remained closed. FK
Posts.Title: Abdominal wound issues after Tram Flap Reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi! Just want to give you some food for thought regarding reconstruction. I had bilateral mastectomies with reconstruction 10 years ago (all covered by insurance). There may not be a medical reason for the reconstruction, but there is definitely an emotional one. Once my cancer treatment was finished and my reconstruction was completed, I felt whole again. I looked good with and without clothes. I would venture to say that my reconstructed breasts look better than the big floppy original equipment LOL! Don't discount your emotional well being. It is all part of the healing process. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Needle biopsy

Posts.Content:
Your mom is very lucky to have found her cancer early! That is our best defense against this disease. Once she has her cancer classified as to type and stage (whether or not it has spread) she will know what to expect. Her age and whether or not she is post menapause can also influence how aggressive the cancer is.  My cancer was also about
 the size of a chickpea; it had not spead out of the breast and was found 5 1/2 years ago! I am still cancer-free! She is lucky to have such a supportive daughter to help her through this uncertan time.  We are her to help both of you get through this! Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: lump in breast

Posts.Content: Hi!
Posts.Title: Going for second biopsy for microcalcifications.

Posts.Content:
This is not unusual.  The imaging field of the CT scan is larger than the area of interest, in your case the kidney. The entire field is viewed and examined by the radiologist and often other things are found.  Your doctors are to be commended for following up! Mammograms are often followed by ultra sound because they give the doctors more detail if there is an area of concern. Most lesions found in the breast are benign, as you have already experienced. Try not to worry until all the tests are completed and you know if there is something to worry about
! Good luck!
Posts.Title: 3rd call back has anyone experienced this...

Posts.Content: It seems to me that you have enough family history to warrent some concern. Genetic testing is not something to fear; it provides valuble information. Being well informed helps us make important decisions. There will be many treatment options presented to you, even if this turns out to be benign. You are your best advocate. Now is the best time to learn as much as you can so you can make to right choices for you! I have a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer. 10 years ago I enrolled in a special breast surveillence program for high risk women at a major brest cancer center in NY. They found my cancer very  early on an MRI. It did not show up on either mammo  or ultasousnd. You might have similar options.  Good luck with your biopsy! Let us know how you make out.  We are here to help you through this!
Posts.Title: Newbie with questions

Posts.Content: Dear MK,
Posts.Title: My daughter Carolyn
High Antinuclear Antibody Count & Cancer

Posts.Content:
Hi Janice,
It seems you and your doctors have formulated a plan! Tests and treatments will become a full time job forthe next 6 months or so. This journey will take you down a bumpy road and you will be on an emotional rollercoaster. This is normal. We have all experienced it. We are here to help you through this. Please keep us in the loop!
Frayda
Posts.Title: Post op visit with Rad Oncologist, with surprising information

Posts.Content: Hi Lori! Your post made me smile as I remembered Mel. She was with us in Myrtle Beach and was so upbeat even though she was really sick! All this pink stuff reminds me of our PPE (pink pony express) and all our sisters that we have lost since that weekend we all met. Sending you a great big (((((HUG))))! Frayda
Posts.Title: Thought of our sweet Mel today...

Posts.Content:
Hi! Welcome to our board. Your sister is lucky to have your support! There are many drugs that are used to fight metastatic BC (mets). Many oncologists think of mets as a chronic disease that can be controlled, if it responds to therapy. There seems to be a "laundry list" of drugs that they refer to, and if the first drug doesn't work, they try the next one on the list. 
 is the most comprehensive site with breast cancer info. That's a good place to start. There are many women here who are going through similar situations and will chime in with more specific info. The board seems to be a bit "sleepy" as of late, so don't be afraid to come back with more questions and more people may respond and help you! Good luck to both of you!
Posts.Title: breast cancer metastasized/treatments
Herceptin and teeth

Posts.Content:
Hi! I am not Stage IV either, but my sister is with similar mets to the lung and pleural lining. She had been on the same drugs you have been on without much success. Her newest regimen is xeloda and ixempra which has brought her tumor markers from 1500 down to 280 in about
 4 months! Her onc keeps saying there are still plenty of options if this combo stops working, Good luck FK
Posts.Title: Stage IV breast cancer survivors

Posts.Content:
Angel, The black staining is superficial and can be removed by a cleaing from your dentist or dental hygienist. For the sensitivity of the roots, you should use the mouthwash, ACT, which is available over the counter and is used daily. It has fluoride in it which reduces sensitivity and cavities. 
FK
Posts.Title: Herceptin and Zometa
Post op visit with Rad Oncologist, with surprising information
Looking for advice on a couple of lumps
Asymmetric Breast Density... Should I be worried?!

Posts.Content: Unfortunately there is not much that you can do.  Your doctor can request a review, but he will have to document that the service he provided was more complex that the routine procedure that the benefit allowance was based. The benefit allowances are set by the insurance company themselves.  Your doctor has no obligation to accept what the insurance company considers "usual and customary", therefore you are responsible for the doctor's full fee.  It is very misleading to consumers when the large print on your insurance policy says they will pay 80% of the UCR.  You are then really responsible for everything that is not covered by the insurance which can amount to thousands of dollars in unexpected expenses. That is how an indemnity plan works; there is no panel of participating doctors that have agreed to accept the fee allowances. When a doctor signs a contract with a PPO or HMO the doctor has agreed to accept the insurance fees and the patient is responsible for only his/her co-pay. Hope this is helpful.
Posts.Title: Anyone know how to increase insurance reimbursements to dr
OK Ladies, I have a question about reconstruction and insurance
Need your wisdom on DCIS
Osteonecrotic Jaw (ONJ)
Thyroid cancer is another gift that keeps on giving...
My Sis in Law is loosing her battle need support

Posts.Content:
I had expanders and then saline implants 8 years ago.  I don't know if things have changed since then, but I have been very happy with my results.  The expansion took place over about
 6 weeks; every week the ps would add saline to the expanders depending how much stretching you could tolerate.  The plan is to "over expand" so that the skin stretches to more then is actually needed which allows for the ps to create a natural fold when the final implant is placed.  I did not think it was painful, just felt a lot of pressure for a few days after each expansion. Once the final expansion is done, things are left alone for about
 three months so that the new skin can "set".  If you have specific questions, I'd be happy to help. FK
Posts.Title: Reconstruction?

Posts.Content:
Hi! Welcome to our board! First I want you to take a deep breath. We have a saying around here to try not to worry until you know there is something to worry about
 (easier said than done!). Yes, I have had a similar experience (and family history!). Let me applaud your doctors for their thoroughness! Early detection is our best defense in treating bc.  They are doing everything by the book in following the newest recommendations for screening high risk patients. 6mm is very small (about
 the size of a grain of barley) and therefore unlikely to be palpated (felt). If it does turn out to be positive for bc, you will be fortunate that it was discovered so early and treatable. Hopefully, it will be benign; the odds are in your favor that most lumps (80%) are benign. If it is not, you have been aniticipating this for a long time and should be prepared to do what ever you need to cure it. My MRI in 2000 showed 3 lesions: 9mm, 7mm and 5mm; none showed on mammo or u/s, all positive. It is now 8 years later and I am fine!!! You will be, too! We are here to help you. Try not to worry too much at this point. Good luck! FK
Posts.Title: Freaked Out!!
EIGHT Year anniversary!
sad news

Posts.Content:
I think staying within your insurance at this point is a good idea. A biopsy can be done anywhere, and NYU is a great place. Once you know what you are dealing with, then there will be decisions to make. Hopefully, things will turn out just fine!
Frayda
Posts.Title: NYC breast surgeon?

Posts.Content: It is a good thing that you are staying on top of this! They will probably call you back for additonal views and an u/s. There are new recommendations for screening "high risk" breast cancer patients that include MRI if nothing shows up on the mammo or u/s. Young women have dense breast tissue and mammo and u/s can miss things. I was in a similar situation eight years ago; my mother and sister both had bc. I know that feeling in your gut that it is "just a matter of time". Make sure you follow up on this, because you are right, early detection saves lives! Good luck! FK
Posts.Title: My first call back

Posts.Content:
Hi Tammy! I was in a similar situation 3 years ago. I know how hard it is not to worry, but it is not time yet! There are lots of things it could be other than cancer. A pulmonary specialist should look at the scans and evaluate the situation.  In my case, several small nodules appeared in a routine CT scan. Since I wasn't having any symptoms, he recommended taking another scan in 3 months to see if there was any change. They remained unchanged for a year. (taking CT scans every 3 months.) Then I had an episode of coughing up blood which occured 6 weeks after the previous scan. I had another scan then and one of the nodules grew to the size of a quarter in less than 6 weeks. To make a very long story short, I developed a very rare form of TB called atypical TB from being immunosupressed. It was not the contagious type. I was treated with antibiotics for 18 months and the condition is currently stable. I still have several nodules that have remained unchanged. I have graduated to getting scanned every 6 months as long as I remain stable. I am NOT implying that this is what you have, but it is only an example of something other than cancer! My pulmonologist said if he scanned 10 random people off the street, 9 of them would have some type of abnormal result. Most of these are benign nodules that are nothing to worry about
. Once we have cancer, everything else that would happen in a "normal" person and seem routine, becomes terrifying when it happens to us.  I certainly would not accept waiting a year! Check with your oncologist or find a good pulmonologist and let him check you out. I hope this has helped. Hugs, Frayda
Posts.Title: Lung Nodule???

Posts.Content:
Lori is correct: they found invasive and non-invasive cells in the biopsy, which may have led the doctors to do the MRI because they suspect there is more than one tumor. Non-invasive cells are DCIS (ductal carcinoma in-situ). It is not uncommon to find DCIS along with invasive tumor. The MRI is more sensitive than the mammo or u/s. My cancer was not seen on either mammo or u/s, only on MRI. That's why they have to do an MRI guided biopsy: it's the only way to find the tumors! I had the MRI back in 2000 as part of the landmark MRI study for high risk breast cancer patients. When they located the tumors (I had 3) they marked them with titanium needles. Then they took another mammo to check if they could see the tumors with the needle markers. The tumors still didn't show on the mammo, only the needles! Thanks to that study, MRI is used routinely now. I guess I was one of the reasons to support MRI screening for high risk patients! The MRI will help your doctors determine the extent of your cancer and plan your treatment.
Good luck!
Posts.Title: evasive/non-evasive

Posts.Content: Ellen, I think Dr. Love was misquoted. I didn't hear that broadcast, but have heard other doctors that refer to metastatic breast cancer as incurable, but controlable for a long time. The longer we can control it, the greater the chance of finding a cure before it is too late. My sister has mets to the lung and is responding well to Taxitere. But we know all too well, it is not a cure. I hope that Mrs. Edwards finds the magic potion that will work for her! FK
Posts.Title: Elizabeth Edwards has mets

Posts.Content:
I had the first implant replaced about
 4 months after the original. Right from the beginning, the right implant had problems: it swelled up twice the size as the left side and took a really long time for the swelling to go down. Then it felt like a rock (compared to the right side). It turned out to be capsular constricture and had to be replaced. My ps said he had never seen that happen so quickly before. He said I had formed a lot of scar tissue around the implant. Maybe my RA had something to do with that (autoimmune response). Then a year and a half later, the same side began leaking (it got noticably smaller) so we replaced it again! That was three years ago, and so far, so good! He said the average life of an implant is 10 years, so replacement must be fairly common and insurance companies have to deal with it. Again, hope all is well! 
Frayda
Posts.Title: Question for those with implants.....

Posts.Content: Hi Martha! Welcome to our board! I had a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction (expanders/implants). The reconstruction definately added to the recovery and amount of discomfort.  I have also had abdominal surgery and the mastectomy was somewhat easier. You will have drains for a week to 10 days which are uncomfortable. Loose shirts that button down the front and safety pins for the drains are a must!  Even if everything goes well and you are feeling good after two weeks, remember that it is still major surgery and you need to give yourself time to heal. Don't go back to work too soon; I'd give yourself a month to take it easy if you can. I thought I was was feeling good enough to go back to the office after a week, just a few hours a day; not a good idea! After a month I almost collapsed from exhaustion.  I am happy to say that was almost 6 years ago and everything is fine now! We will try to help you in anyway we can. We have lots of experiences among us that you can help you navigate your road through treatment and recovery. Just ask! Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: Mastectomy April 30th

Posts.Content:
Hi! Welcome to our board! I was treated at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (
). The breast center is located at 205 64th St.  They have several great breast surgeons; I was treated by Alexandra Heerdt who was wonderful! I was in their breast surveillence program for high risk patients back in 2000 because my mom and sister both had bc. My bc was picked up on a screening MRI. You can go on their website for lots of info on breast cancer in general.  If you have specific questions, I'd be happy to help. Try not to worry yet. Most lumps (80%) turn out to be benign! It is good that you are checking this out.
Posts.Title: NYC breast surgeon?

Posts.Content: Hi, Gail! I did have to replace an implant, twice! Insurance paid both times.  I think they are obligated because it is related to mastectomy reconstruction.  Dealing with insurance companies as a profession, I know that if they can figure out a way not to pay, they will! You have to know your rights and fight them if they try to weasle out of it. Hope all is well! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Question for those with implants.....

Posts.Content:
Hi Cathi!
It's great to see your post! Sending hugs and positive thoughts your way!
L & H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Hi Friends

Posts.Content: Congratulations on a benign report! FYI, the presence of "atypical hyperplasia" is exactly what you said: an abnormal increase in the number of normal cells. This is sometimes used as an indication that you may be at a slightly higher risk than usual to develop a cancer (remember I said slight!) and that is why the recommended follow-up.  Just make sure you follow your doctor's recommendations for future visits and mammos. Wishing you continued good health! FK
Posts.Title: Follow up on lumpectomy...

Posts.Content:
Congratulation, my friend! Glad to have shared the journey with you! Wishing you many more years of health and happiness!
L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Seven years and counting!!!
Remission question
Barretts asophigus

Posts.Content: I share your joy on celebrating six years! Unfortunately for me, this has been a very sad time. My mother lost her battle with breast/ovarian cancer last Saturday, May 27. I was able to fly down to Florida on Friday evening (it was very hard getting a flight siince it was a holiday weekend!) and I was with her as she passed on Saturday. I think she was waiting for me to get there! Now she has joined our other sisters who are watching over us! Please keep my sister, Shelley, in your prayers; she is still struggling with her fight against lung mets. This has been a very difficult time for us!
Posts.Title: Congatulations, Gail! It's my anniversary, too!
ovaries

Posts.Content: Mazel Tov, Luci! Life can be good! Best wishes to you and your ever expanding family! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Now this is really good news.....
Just finished bi-lateral mastectomy and tissue explander surgery...

Posts.Content:
Hi Linda! Welcome to our little part of cyberspace! Sorry you have to be here, but as you can see, we are here to help! You have already gotten some great advise. I had a bilateral mastectomy with expanders 5 1/2 years ago. The drains stay in anywhere between one to two weeks, depending on when the amount of fluid gets down to less than 30 cc per day (that number may be different today) One side on me dried up faster than the other but I think they were both ready to come out about
 day 10. Depending on your job, you should try to stay home as long as you can (at least three weeks).  This is major surgery and your body will have sustained quite an insult, so you will need plenty of rest to give your body a chance to heal. I thought I could handle going back a few hours a day after a week.  After three weeks, I thought I was going to crash! I took another full week off just to rest and then came back again part time for another three weeks before trying full time.  I had a hard time sleeping on my back. I did experience muscle spasms in my chest during the expansion period. My dr. gave me a prescript
ion for a muscle relaxer which also helped me sleep. They will show you stretching exercises to do to increase your range of motion in your arms. Make sure you do them! You will start out easy at first , then increase slowly until you can get your arms above your head. Good luck! If you have any specific questions, I'd be happy to help! Frayda
Posts.Title: Would really like some help...

Posts.Content: For those of you who may remember, both my mom and my sister have been dealing with mets, and things are not going well. My mom was treated for ovarian ca last year and she just began hospice care this week.  She wants to be home, and hospice has been wonderful providing the care and support she needs. I don't know how long she has, but she is loosing ground quickly. My dad is there with her (in Florida) and I am flying back and forth from NJ. My sister is in retreatment in PA, but her tumor markers keep going up, so she is getting frustrated. Please keep us all in your prayers! I'll try to keep you posted... L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Prayer request.....

Posts.Content:
Thank you! This is as close to a "group hug" as I can get! You ladies are terrific; I think of you often and wish you all well!
Love, Frayda
Posts.Title: Prayer request.....

Posts.Content: I am happy to say that I am fine now! That's not to say that there weren't a few bumps along the way. I did have to have one implant replaced twice; first due to constricture after just a few months and then a year later due to leakage. It's been three years since the last replacement and everything looks good. As a matter of fact, I am going for my routine follow-up with my breast surgeon tomorrow. Be sure you and your plastic surgeon are on the same page concerning your expectation of what size you want to be in the end. My idea of smaller and his were not the same. When I was getting expanded I kept saying "enough!" and he kept saying "just a little more!" He explained he had to overfill the expanders so there would be a natural fold with the final implants. He spoke in terms of cc and I spoke cup size; not the same! I ended up 450 cc, a large c cup; I wanted to be full b cup! After all is said and done, they do look great in clothes and I am in proportion. Most of us who have had reconstruction has needed some adjustments here and there. It's part of the game plan. I hope everything goes smoothly with yours! Frayda
Posts.Title: Would really like some help...

Posts.Content: My cancer did not show up on mammo or u/s either, but it did show up on an MRI.  If you have dense breast tissue tumors are often missed on mammo and u/s.  Breast MRI is fairly new technology and not all radiology facilities are able to provide them. MRI is also "too" sensitive, and results in many false positives. There are certain criteria that determine the indications for MRI use in breast imaging; high risk and dense breasts are among them. They are also costly so your insurance may make it difficult to get one. But as the others have already said, a biopsy is the only way to know what is there for sure! Good luck! We will be hoping for benign results!Frayda
Posts.Title: One Appt Down!
What is the difference in care at top cancer centers (esp sloan kettering, hopkins, MD Anderson)

Posts.Content: Dear Lori,
Posts.Title: Chapters ending and starting....

Posts.Content: Hi Chantry! Welcome to our board! I also come from a very stong family history of bc and have made choices based on the history. I've found that the genetic testing doesn't necessarily help; my mother, sister and three maternal aunts all had bc but neither me, my mom or sister tested positive for BRCA 1 or 2! The assumption was that there is another gene in my family and we should proceed as if my bc is hereditary and follow the same protocols. I opted for bilateral mastectomy w/ reconstruction and down the road I had a bilateral oopherectomy (ovaries & fallopian tubes). Turned out my mom had ovarian ca, too! If you have any specific questions I'll be happy to share. You are on the right track being your own advocate! Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: Chantry....

Posts.Content: Having a single cell found in a pathology specimen is not very significant, especially since its appearence is questionable. A megakaryocyte is a speicalized blood cell involved in making platelets. A more common multinucleated cell that is normally found in connective tissue is called a macrophage. A lymph node is a specialized connective tissue.  I think the mention of this cell was just an observation, not really influencing the diagnosis.  Enjoy your otherwise good news! Hugs, Frayda
Posts.Title: Pathology report question

Posts.Content: It shouldn't matter when you decide to do the reconstruction. As an expert in dealing with insurance companies as it relates to oral and maxillofacial surgery, it always pays to speak to an insurance rep BEFORE surgery to find out what is covered and what needs pre-certification. If they give you any hint that any of this may be considered cosmetic, read them the riot act! What ever you decide to do, it is all medically necessary under the law! Your surgeon must have staff that deals with this all the time. They should be doing this on your behalf. In today's insurance climate, most hospital admissions must be pre-certified, which the doctor's office must obtain before the surgery. It wouldn't hurt to call them and make sure everything is in order. Hugs, Frayda
Posts.Title: New Diagnosis of Infiltrating Lobular Breast Cancer Here

Posts.Content: Hi Michelle! Lori is right. Sounds like someone at your doctor's office may have dropped the ball and you got lost between the cracks. It's good that your followed up! Your onc would not have gotten the results unless you or the requesting doc instructed the radiologist to send a report there also. You are entitled to a copy of that report, too. All you have to do is call the imaging center and request it. Someone here may be able to help you interpret it. I have had several MRI's of my spine because funky spots have appeared. They haven't changed over 2 years so the docs feel it can't be mets, only anomalies (variations in anatomy that is normal for me). So it is good you had another MRI to compare it to. Hope it turns out to be another pork chop bone! Hugs, Frayda
Posts.Title: MRI report
Bi-lat mast w/DIEP flaps.-implants&donor site revision sched 10/13/05-anyone had this?I have ?'s
Weill Cornell Breast Center

Posts.Content:
Hi Cathy! Welcome to our board! Yes, your insurance will pay for the other breast.  The federal regulation requires insurance to pay for any surgery that restores symetry, whether it be mastectomy & reconstruction or augmentation. I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate recon with expanders and implants. I went back to work about
 six days after my surgery (drains tucked inside!). That was a mistake! After several weeks I was emotionally and physically exhausted! Your body will have gone through a significant trauma and will need time to heal.  Don't short change yourself! You have people who love you and will help you; let them! Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: New Diagnosis of Infiltrating Lobular Breast Cancer Here

Posts.Content: I'm glad you all came with me to my doctor's visit because things have gotten a little scary the past two days.  Two nights ago I coughed up some significant blood. I went to my pulmonary doctor the next day and he ordered a CT scan. It showed that one of those nodules that we have been watching since last year suddenly got a lot bigger since the last scan 6 weeks ago. Since I was seeing the doctor at Sloan Kettering today, I brought the scan with me. She took the bloodwork for the tumor markers and ordered a PET scan that I waited around for. Thanks,guys, for being so patient! Well, that area definately lit up but I won't get an official report until next week. I brought a copy of the scan to my doctor here in NJ and he sceduled a bronchoscopy for Tuesday. So ladies, please come back here to NJ on Tuesday! Looks like I'm starting my own fireworks a little early(heh-heh). Everyone have a nice holiday! I'll keep you posted...L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Thanks everyone for coming with me today, but sorry it took so long......

Posts.Content:
Make sure all is in order by today. Don't assume anything is ok. It is the anesthesiologist that is going to want to be sure you are medically cleared for surgery. He won't put you under if there is a question about
 the clearance. Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: medical clearance
"See ya next year," said the oncologist.....

Posts.Content: Thanks for asking, Jennifer! She had bloodwork done yesterday so we won't know until next week if there has been any improvement yet. But she says she is feeling OK. Frayda
Posts.Title: Att Frayda
prayer request in NJ again

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone! I met with the infectious disease doctor yesterday. He reassured me that I am not contagious and explained how my surpressed immune system allowed this bacteria to grow in my lungs. He said it can be a stubborn infection and will need to take all the antibiotics for a year at least. Who would think I would be thrilled with TB! Now I have to meet with my rheumatologist and adjust my arthritis meds. I am looking foward to visiting my son and his fiance in Boston this weekend with a clear head! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Bronchoscopy update.....

Posts.Content:
I have my six month check-up with the breast surgeon this Thursday. Since I saw her in December, my mom was diagnosed with advanced ovarian cancer and my sister with bc lung mets. Obviously, I am quite nervous and have many questions for her. For those of you who may remember, I also have had some funky results with past spine and lung scans that we have been "watching".  I think I should get some tumor markers for starters. Anyone know which ones to ask about
? I have never had any because I was originally node negative. I think I will also ask about
 a PET scan to see if anything corresponds to the other scans. Any other suggestions? Please send the PCE on NJ Transit to NYC to keep my company on my way to Sloan Kettering! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Routine check-up on Thursday.....

Posts.Content: Well, I had a repeat CT scan today and the lesion is unchanged.  I think the doctor had hoped that it would be smaller, hence not a tumor but probably an infection or some other annoyance. So we proceded to schedule the lung needle biopsy at Sloan Kettering, but they can't do it until July 26! UGH! My doctor here in NJ said it is a very tricky procedure made much more difficult by my implants. My doctor at Sloan Kettering agreed that it can be very tricky and would prefer I do it there. I guess the two biggest concerns are a possible collapsed lung or a deflated implant! So the waiting continues..... L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Update on lung biopsy...

Posts.Content: I am so sorry she is going through this again! Please tell her we are all praying for her! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Cathi was admitted again!

Posts.Content:
DH stayed with me and he asked me about
 the pink feathers! We got some preliminary reports from the Bronchoscopy which were negative (he couldn't get the scope all the way to the lesion); the cultures for the possible infection will take a few weeks to come back.  DH & I will see the doctor tomorrow to discuss the next step.  I think the lung biopsy will be in order. I don't want to wait a few weeks for the cultures; the pathologist agreed to go ahead with the biopsy. So now we'll see how quickly that can be arranged. I'll let you know! Frayda
Posts.Title: Thanks ladies for being in the OR yesterday.....

Posts.Content: Thank you, everyone! My doctor from Sloan Kettering called me this morning;the results from the PET were highly suspicious for malignancy but the tumor markers were all normal. The only "hot" spot was that nodule. So the plan is to have the bronchoscopy here on Tuesday and then schedule a regular lung biopsy at Sloan. I have a very busy weekend planned, including the wedding of a very close friend's son on Sunday so I will have plenty of things to distract me.  Thank you for the invite, Laure, but as you can see, I will be well occupied. Another time, for sure!. I love you guys! Frayda
Posts.Title: Thanks everyone for coming with me today, but sorry it took so long......

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone! Today is my 5 year anniversary from diagnosis.  I am happy to say that all is well.  I will have my official check-up in a few weeks, but I am feeling fine! I didn't think I was going to feel any different, but the weird thing is that I do seem to feel that something has be lifted off my shoulders. Here's looking foward to us all being here to celebrate the next 5! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: 5 YEARS! YEAH!!!!!

Posts.Content: We finally got results on the cultures from the bronchoscopy: atypical tuberculosis. Believe it or not, that is good news! That's what the doctors were hoping for since this is treatable and curable. This form is also not contagious. Apparently, when your immune system is compromised such as by chemo or HIV, you are susceptible to this infection.  These bacteria are always present in the air, but healthy people are resistant to them. When your immune system is supressed like mine is with long term use of methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis, you can get this infection. My pulmonary doctor started me on a TB drug regimen (4 antibiotics!) and we cancelled the lung biopsy. My doctor at Sloan Kettering is pleased with this news, too! We are going to repeat the CT scan in 6 weeks. Hopefully, we should see an improvement by then. Thank you for helping me through this! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Bronchoscopy update.....

Posts.Content: Hi Arlene, sure I remember you! I even remember you used to live in NJ, too! I don't think I would be comfortable waiting 5 or 6 months. I would see a breast surgeon and your ps should be able to recommend one. If the lump doesn't show up on the u/s, the only way to biopsy it is with an MRI guided biopsy and the breast surgeon would know if that can be done at that center. Either way, the breast surgeon should be the one to consult. Welcome back! Frayda
Posts.Title: MK or JoAnn

Posts.Content:
Thank you, everyone! And Thanks Jen & Deb for the encouraging info on Femara. This certainly put my sister's mind at ease! Her tumor marker is normally around 30 and this past month it jumped to 138. That is when her onc ordered the CT scan which showed the lung nodules and was confirmed with the PET scan. Her onc was very optomistic about
 the Femara. Thanks again! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: My sister has bc mets to the lung....

Posts.Content:
Some of you may remember that my sister was diagnosed about
 6 months before me (that's what prompted my MRI). She was IIB with one positive node. She just found out that she has several small bc nodes in her lungs.  She was going to have her last tamoxifen in August.  Her onc stopped the tamoxifen and put her on Femara. She said she has had good results with keeping the mets in check with Femara, so she is trying this first.  If her tumor markers don't go down in a couple of months, then she said there are other drugs to try.  Any experience out there with these meds or lung mets? Shelley (my ds) and I could certainly use some prayers and hugs! Thanks! I will keep you posted! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: My sister has bc mets to the lung....

Posts.Content:
Hi Lisa! Welcome to our little section of cyberspace! I have had experience with the MRI. I was part of that big study that was using MRI for screening high risk women for breast cancer (my mother and sister had bc).  The results found that the MRI is definately a good idea for high risk, but not for the general population because of the high percentage of false positives.  They found a significant number of early cancers that were not found on mammogram or ultrasound.  I was one of them! Both my mammo and u/s were "normal"! I was 44 at the time and had large dense breasts. They may not have found anything on a mammo until things  got much larger and I might not be here five years later talking about
 it! Your radiation treatment puts you in the high risk category and I commend your doctor for suggesting the MRI. He really has your best interest at heart.  I am not suggesting that you may have cancer, but this is certainly one of the better diagnostic tools for early detection and that is surely our best defense against this disease. Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: MRI for screening

Posts.Content: Erin, funny you should ask! I had a bilateral and my nipple on the left side really flattened out and that is the side I sleep on. I never put 2 and 2 together! The right side got a little smaller over time (4 years) but it still looks pretty good considering. I had asked my ps why one side flattened more than the other and he just shrugged. I think we are on to something! Frayda
Posts.Title: Nipple reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Teresa, there is no hurry to do the nipples; that can be done any time. I am very happy with mine. It really made me feel completely "put back together" like Humpty Dumpty! They do stay erect, and I didn't want a full "salute" so we kept them modest. But after time, they will flatten out anyway. This is fine with me because I go braless a lot and nobody can tell. They still resemble real breasts (not exactly) so I think that is important for the self-esteem part. I had to have the tatoo redone once because it didn't all take the first time. There was about
 a six month wait time for the retouching because of waiting for complete healing from the first round (something to do with risking infection). I don't remember how long I had to wait before getting them wet, but I think it was a couple of weeks. Have a great time on your cruise; you can take care of this when you get back! L&H, Frayda

Posts.Title: Finally............
PCE, ready to board for NJ.....

Posts.Content: Hi Laure! I had multifocal and multicentric DCIS with microinvasions.  Multifocal means multiple lesions in the same quadrant of the breast while multicentric means lesions in more than one quadrant.  My cancer was not visible on mammo or u/s. Three lesions were found on an MRI, which turned out to be the DCIS. My surgeon recommended a mastectomy due to the multicentric issue. If the lesions were confined to a single quadrant, she said we could consider a lumpectomy with radiation.  She also felt there was a good chance there would be additional DCIS scattered throughout the breast, which would be likely to result in a recurrence if I chose a partial mastectomy.  Since I was very high risk anyway (mother and sister had bc) I chose a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction (saline implants). I needed reconstruction on the mastectomy, so I felt it was worth the peace of mind to do the prophylactic mastectomy at the same time and the reconstruction would be symetrical. The final pathology revealed 5 additional areas of DCIS in the cancer breast and several areas of DCIS and LCIS on the prophylactic side! For me, this was obviously the right choice. If you have any specific questions, I would be happy to help. Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: Anyone with experience with multi-focal DCIS?

Posts.Content: Laure, good luck with your move! You are coming up to New Jersey, right? I live in Edison which is north central NJ. Welcome to the "neighborhood"! Hope all goes well! Hugs, Frayda

And try not to let them get too full; that makes them heavy. Gentle hugs, Frayda

Posts.Title: Can the PCE make a stop in NJ tomorrow?

Posts.Content: We have a saying here not to worry until you know there is something to worry about! Keep in mind that about 80% of the time these thing are BENIGN. But this is exactly why we recommend that everything be biopsied; it is the only way to know for sure what something is! A doctor can make an educated guess as to the appearance of a lesion on a mammo or u/s, but these tests are not diagnostic. We will be waiting with you for your results and hope that they are B9! Hugs, Frayda

Once there is a discrepancy in the reports, it may be helpful to have the same set of eyes reviewing both sets of slides. You can ask your oncologist about this and he can arrange to have this done. There should be no additional cost to you, if this was already covered by your insurance.

Posts.Title: Anyone remember the pork chop bone story??

Posts.Content: I have been watching this very closely, and I am disappointed that it has not been approved.  I had saline implants placed almost 5 years ago and after some early problems with constricture and leakage, they have been satisfactory in restoring form and function but have never been happy with the way they feel.  I have rheumatoid arthritis and my rheumatologist did not feel comfortable giving me the green light for silicone until they were "prooven" safe and was FDA approved. My ps wouldn't consider them without the approval of my rheumatologist. I agree Candy, almost everything in medicine has risks associated with it. The medications I take for the arthritis have some potentially dangerous side effects. In fact Bextra is one of them and the FDA has recently recommended it be pulled from the market! This will probably result in switiching to another potentially dangerous drug that may not work as well as the Bextra did. Well, the opposition may have won this battle, but the war is far from over! Frayda

She is still trying to be upbeat, but I can tell this is getting to her.  I am going to Florida next week for a few days to check up on her. Maybe the PCE can make a stop in Del Ray Beach? I'll let you know how she makes out! You guys are the best!  Hugs, Frayda

Posts.Title: Friday 3/4

Posts.Content: Hi Carol! I want to add my welcome and 2 cents, too. If your husband is disabled and on public assistance, doesn't he have a case worker assigned? There is care giving assistance available, but the social worker must make the arrangements. There may be assistance for you also, should it be necessary. You need to let social services get involved and let the system work for you. With your family bc history, you are certainly considered high risk, whether or not you take the BRCA test. Even if this episode turns out OK (and I hope it does!) you will need to be followed very carefully in the future. There are special high risk protocols that you should discuss with you doctor. Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: New Here

Posts.Content: I think you are more frightened about having a breast biopsy than this procedure in particular.  Did your doctor find something on a mammogram that needed to be tested? Let me try to reassure you that breast lumps are very common, but most of the time they are benign.  The only way to know for sure is to biopsy it.  A stereotactic needle biopsy is one way to do this. A special computer finds the breast lesion and then the technician "locks" the breast in position for the radiologist take one or more samples of the lesion with needle, which feels like a bee sting. It may take several days to get the results, which is the hardest part of any test. We will be here to help you wait for your results, which we all hope will be benign! Welcome to our board.  You will find us a wealth of information and support. Let us know a little more about you, if you'd like (we are a nosy bunch, too!) Good luck! Frayda
Posts.Title: stereotactic needle biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Gail! Sounds like you found a great doc! The Arthrotec is a NSAID - non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug.  All these drugs take time to build up an optimal blood level, sometimes 6 weeks until it reaches the peak effectiveness. So be patient; it's a good sign that you have gotten some relief already. Hope this really helps. Good luck! Frayda

St. Clare's Hospital in Dover, NJ is an affiliate of Sloan Ketteing Cancer Center in NY and has breast cancer specialists rotating through there.  Dover is not far from Lafayette.  I was treated at Sloan Kettering in NY and they have the reputation of having the best cancer treatment in the world. Meanwhile, I will join the B9 mantra and hope that you won't be needing it! Good Luck! Frayda

Posts.Title: Difficult Time

I wonder how many of us had similar biopsy histories prior to a cancer diagnosis? Guess it just goes to show, every biopsy counts! Hugs, Frayda
Posts.Title: stereotactic needle biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi ladies! Let me put my dental hygienist's cap on and shed a little light on what's happening. Chemo can make your gums more susceptible to periodontal (gum) disease and that results in gum recession.  When your gums receed, your roots get exposed and that is what is so sensitive.  Your roots are not covered by the protective enamel, so your teeth become very sensitive to hot, cold and sweet.  You can reduce some of the sensitivity by using a fluoride mouth wash (like Act) daily or a special desensitizing toothpaste like Sensodyne. Exposed root surfaces are very likely to decay, so that eventually contributes to the sensitivity.  Brushing and flossing are the best way to prevent that, in addition to regular visits with your hygienist! L&H, Frayda

Posts.Title: Just found a lump...

Posts.Content: The itching can also come from stretching the skin during the expansion process. I would caution against using the creams because of the new incisions; many of the anti-itch creams have various forms of steroids in them (such as hydrocortisone) and that can delay or interfere with the healing process. Moist heat from a warm wash cloth will give some temporary relief and you can do that as often as you want. Also, use a moisturizer daily to keep the skin soft. Vitamin E is supposed to help healing and prevent scarring, but don't use it until the incisions have closed completely. Frayda

Posts.Title: finally home....

Posts.Content:
Hi Luci!
Glad there isn't anything serious going on. If DH has to go back to NY for regular visits anyway, then staying with the NY doc is ok for now. The problem is if anything serious develops, then you have to stay in NY or scramble to find someone in LV. Did the LV doc leave the phone messages himself or was it his office staff? If it was him, then I would guess he was trying to make ammends. My DH genuinely feels bad when patients have to wait a long time for an appointment, but sometimes unforseen things happen that can really throw a schedule off. We always let the patients know if there is going to be a delay so that the patient can decide if they want to reschedule. If it was the office staff that called, then he was just CHA (covering his a**) to document that they tried to reach you about having that test! Either way, you got off on the wrong foot with this office. If you really like this doc, then you have to look past the office staff. Otherwise, you are best getting a fresh start with someone new. L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Bladder problem caused by cytoxan

Posts.Content: Hi Christina! Welcome to our Board! Lori gave you great information. Some cancers are just very difficult to detect with traditional tests, especially if your mom has very dense breasts. The MRI, even though it is more sensitive that mammography and ultra sound, still is not 100% accurate. I agree with Lori that your mom should consult a major cancer center where state of the art and cutting edge technology is available, especially since your mom's cancer is being so ellusive. BTW, loosing her breast is not so awful; it will be difficult at first but if she chooses, there are great reconstruction options. I had bilateral mastectomies with reconstruction and I am very happy with the results. You and your mom should come here with questions. Collectively we have had many different experiences and are able to offer assitance in deciphering all the information that will be thrown at you in the beginning. Your mom is very lucky to have you to help her through this troubling time! Good Luck! Frayda

I plan to go down there for a few days after her surgery.  It is so hard dealing with this long distance! Wishing you all well! L & H, Frayda

Posts.Title: Possibly bc

Posts.Content: Luci, I heard that story about Celebrex, too.  I also heard one about an investigation of Bextra.  I am takeing Bextra for my rheumatoid arthritis. The truth is, if aspirin was first marketed today, it would never pass the stringent FDA regulations for release! Any medication you take has risks associated with it; it's better that hurting! Hope the aleve helps! Hugs, Frayda
Posts.Title: Vioxx v. Celebrex and Bextra....

Posts.Content: Vicky, hope all goes well! Just try to snooze; you may find it quite relaxing! Hope it will bring good news and a Happy Anniversary! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Prayers Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Ellen, It's great to get normal results! I know how you feel about reducing your risk. I went through a similar ordeal last year with my ovaries and finally opted for the oopherectomy. Some people thought I was crazy to go through another surgery, but no one but us understand the worry and fear that we can't ignore. Take this for what it is worth, but it did bring me peace of mind. (((HUG!))) Frayda
Posts.Title: normal biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi! Welcome! I had bilateral mastectomies in 8/2000. What you are feeling is not unusual. I had been on an emotional roller coaster, and trust me, it does get better! The women here are a wonderful source of support. Being able to "talk" to someone else who has gone through the same thing is so comforting. I found their caring and support invaluable! One of the most helpful books for me was "Living Beyond Breast Cancer" by Marissa Weiss, MD. She also has a website, www.breastcancer.org that has lots of info and resources. The depression that follows your surgery is common; many of us have sought some professional help to get through it, as medication can help. Share some more info with us so we can better help you. I had reconstruction w/ saline implants. Once the reconstruction was completed, I felt much better; kind of like Humpty Dumpty who was put back together again!LOL! I'd be happy to share my experiences with you! Here's a big ((((HUG)))) to welcome you to our little corner of cyberspace! Frayda
Posts.Title: Emotional response to bi-lateral mastectomies

Posts.Content:
Becky, it good to see your post! I will be sending special prayers your way this Thanksgiving. Enjoy the day!
Frayda
Posts.Title: Hello all !

Posts.Content:
I met Ann Jillian last evening! She performed at a benefit concert with our local symphany orchestra to raise money for our breast center at JFK Medical Center in Edison, NJ! DH & I got to spend some time with her after the concert. (DH is chairman of the board of the hospital). Her successful battle against breast cancer is an inspiration to us all. She was warm and gracious and genuinely interested in my story.  She was incredibly talented as well! I only remember her in her sitcom, "It's A Living" and her TV Movie about
 her bc, but can she sing! Her story gives hope to us all, as she is a 20 year survivor! Happy Halloween everyone! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: Ann Jillian

Posts.Content: Ladies, don't panic! The key words in the article are"bone damage in the jaw if they have major dental work during therapy". That means an invasive procedure such as a root canal, extraction or dental implants. Simple, routine procedures that do not involve contamination of the bone such as cleanings or fillings should not be of concern. Certainly, if you are taking aredia or zometa you need to inform your dentist before any dental treatment. Shells, your symptoms are classic for TMJ and a night guard may certainly help. Your dentist should be able to determine that and make you one. Hugs, Frayda
Posts.Title: WARNING AREDIA AND ZOMETA GIRLS!!!

Posts.Content: Steph, just FYI, my genetic testing is not part of my medical record anywhere. The testing is done anonomously (with an ID#) and my doctors do not mention it in their records. They are very careful to protect your privacy and now with the HIPAA laws, it should be impossible for anyone unauthorized to get that information. Hugs, Frayda

L&H, Frayda

Posts.Title: Finally home!

Posts.Content: Frayda, 50, New Jersey; dx 5/2000, bilateral mastectomy w/ reconstuction w/ saline implants, ovaries removed 4/2003.  Very strong family history of bc: mother (twice!), sister, 3 aunts. Cancer was found on an experimental screening MRI; previous mammo and ultrasound were normal.
Posts.Title: ROLL CALL name, age, state and any other info to share

Posts.Content: The one from the dentist also makes sure your teeth are in proper occlusion (they come together properly). An athletic guard that you buy in the store is not going to protect your teeth against clenching. The dentist is definately the way to go! Frayda
Posts.Title: Lori, about the mouth piece.....

Posts.Content: Luci, I am also relieved that a tumor was not detected on the MRI. However, remember that no imaging modality is definitively diagnostic; it just gives the doctor information. Some types of imaging techniques are better for soft tissue while others are better for hard tissues. The new digital imaging techniques are highly specialized and need to be read accurately by the radiologists.  Whether your doctor has or has not seen the films himself may not mean that he is a bad doctor; he most likely cannot "read" the MRI and is relying on the skills of the radiologist to interpret the study.  He may not be jumping into surgery blindly, but rather wants to see with his eyes what is going on and biopsy anything that appears unusual.  You know the drill: a biopsy is the ONLY way to know what something really is! Even though medicine has come such a long way technologically, there is still a lot of "gut feelings" that guide our physicians to take one coarse or another, and that just comes from experience. A second opinion is certainly in order, especially since you are not comfortable with your original doctor's recommendation. I just want to share with you some perspective from the "other" side. I really do hope this turns out to be just another pork chop bone! L&H, Frayda
Posts.Title: MRI results are in....

Posts.Content: I prefer plain M&Ms: I like to let them melt on my tongue...they last longer! LOL! Hoping and praying for good results, Luci! Have a safe trip home. Hugs, Frayda
